bestBHT.bht: The shepherds, in their simple faith and devoutness, bypassed the angels and their heavenly spectacle. Instead, they responded urgently, saying, Let us go and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us. Their words carried a climactic progression, expressing their deep desire to witness what the Lord had revealed. Their immediate and faithful response reminds us to prioritize God's Word, to act without delay, and to seek the presence of the Savior eagerly.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Let us go and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us."
Lovely simplicity of devoutness and faith this!
They are not taken up with the angels, the glory that invested them, and the lofty strains with which they filled the air.
Albert Barnes: These shepherds appear to have been pious people. They were waiting for the coming of the Messiah.
On the first intimation that he had actually appeared they went with haste to find him. So all people should without delay seek the Saviour.
We have only to cast our eyes to heaven; to look to him and to believe on him, and we shall find him ever near to us, and forever our Saviour and friend.
Marvin Vincent: The preposition dia, through, implies through the intervening space.
The utterance of the shepherds contains a climax: 'Let us go and see this saying, which has come to pass; which the Lord made known.'
The shepherds. Some texts add oiJ anqrwpoi, the men; but the latter texts omit.
John Calvin: Instead of allowing the word of God, as many do, to pass away with the sound, we must take care that it strike its roots deep in us, and manifest its power, as soon as the sound has died away upon our ears.
For this reason, the Lord directs our attention to himself; that we may not fix our view on men, and undervalue the authority of his Word.
In the same manner, every one of us, according to the measure of his faith and understanding, ought to be prepared to follow wheresoever God calls.
Philip Schaff: The angels went to heaven; the shepherds sought what the angels had praised: the former, to continue the song of ‘glory in the highest;’ the latter, to discover ‘peace on earth.’
The simple faith of these shepherds is a token that they were men ‘in whom He is well-pleased’ and hence chosen to receive this revelation.
Archibald T. Robertson: Said to one another (ελαλουν προς αλληλους). Imperfect tense, inchoative, 'began to speak,' each to the other. It suggests also repetition, they kept saying,
This thing (το ρημα τουτο). A Hebraistic and vernacular use of ρημα (something said) as something done.
John Gill: The angels...departed from them: and...the shepherds said one to another, let us now go even to Bethlehem...and see this thing which hath come to pass..." (Luke 2:15).

From whence it appears, that it was not from diffidence...that they moved one another to go to Bethlehem; for they firmly believed the thing was come to pass, which the angel had told them of, and that what he said was from the Lord."

Nor did they act any criminal part, or indulge a vain curiosity, in going to Bethlehem to see what was done; for it seems to be the will of God that they should go, and...be qualified not only as hear, but as eyewitnesses of the truth of this fact, to report it with greater certainty.

bhtAttempts.bht: The shepherds, in their lovely simplicity of devoutness and faith, were not preoccupied with the angels or the glory surrounding them. Instead, moved by an urgent desire, they said to one another, Let us go and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us. Their words contained a climactic progression, emphasizing that they wanted to witness firsthand what the Lord had revealed. It is notable that the text includes the imperfect tense, suggesting that their conversation was not just a one-time moment, but a repetitive and ongoing dialogue. Their faith and obedience are evident in their immediate response, exemplifying their readiness to seek the Savior. We too should prioritize the Word of God and promptly act upon it, allowing it to take root in us and manifest its power in our lives.

The shepherds, with their simple faith and devotion, were not drawn to the angels or their majestic songs. Instead, they urgently said to one another, Let us go and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us. This dialogue demonstrates their eagerness and their firm belief in the message. Their prompt response embodies the kind of faith and obedience that we should strive for when we encounter the Word of God.

In response to the angels' announcement, the shepherds displayed a remarkable simplicity of faith and devoutness. They did not allow themselves to be captivated by the angels or their glorious appearance. Instead, they turned their attention to the message that the Lord had made known to them, saying, Let us go and see this thing which is come to pass. Their words reveal a sense of urgency, an immediate desire to witness the fulfillment of what the Lord had spoken. Their faithful response calls us to prioritize the Word of God, to act upon it promptly, and to seek the Savior with fervor.

The shepherds, in their simple faith and devoutness, bypassed the angels and their heavenly spectacle. Instead, they responded urgently, saying, Let us go and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us. Their words carried a climactic progression, expressing their deep desire to witness what the Lord had revealed. Their immediate and faithful response reminds us to prioritize God's Word, to act without delay, and to seek the presence of the Savior eagerly.

The shepherds, with their lovely simplicity of faith, were not captivated by the angels or their majestic songs. Instead, they urgently said to one another, Let us go and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us. Their response exhibited a firm belief in the message revealed to them. Their immediate obedience and faithful anticipation exemplify the kind of faith we should have when encountering the Word of God.
